user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 8.13.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
The function takes a pointer parameter 'struct MHD_Connection *c' but only reads from the object (accesses c->suspended, c->connection_timeout_ms, c->last_activity and c->daemon) and never modifies *c. According to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 the pointer should point to a const-qualified type when possible. The parameter should be declared as 'const struct MHD_Connection *c' (e.g. static bool connection_check_timedout(const struct MHD_Connection *c)).
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified connection_check_timedout code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/1625.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_check_timedout:
```c
static bool
connection_check_timedout (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  const uint64_t timeout = c->connection_timeout_ms;
  uint64_t now;
  uint64_t since_actv;

  if (c->suspended)
    return false;
  if (0 == timeout)
    return false;
  now = MHD_monotonic_msec_counter ();
  since_actv = now - c->last_activity;
  /* Keep the next lines in sync with #connection_get_wait() to avoid
   * undesired side-effects like busy-waiting. */
  if (timeout < since_actv)
  {
    if (UINT64_MAX / 2 < since_actv)
    {
      const uint64_t jump_back = c->last_activity - now;
      /* Very unlikely that it is more than quarter-million years pause.
       * More likely that system clock jumps back. */
      if (5000 >= jump_back)
      {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                  _ ("Detected system clock %u milliseconds jump back.\n"),
                  (unsigned int) jump_back);
#endif
        return false;
      }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                _ ("Detected too large system clock %" PRIu64 " milliseconds "
                   "jump back.\n"),
                jump_back);
#endif
    }
    return true;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified connection_check_timedout code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original connection_check_timedout with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as connection_check_timedout.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call connection_check_timedout to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of connection_check_timedout as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, connection_check_timedout will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of connection_check_timedout as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
